The DEA recently approved a new oral liq: a synthetic version of the active ingredient in marijuana, as a Schedule II drug.
The approval of this synthetic version o: which is different from recreational "synthetic cannabis" products.
The United States Food and Drug Administ: FDA) approved a New Drug Application for Syndros, an oral solution of the synthetic version of the most prominent psychoactive ingredient in marijuana, for use by AIDS and chemotherapy patients.
The DEA issued a ruling on Syndros: placing it in the Schedule II grouping of drugs with a high potential for abuse, allowing for prescription in a limited fashion. This ruling was adopted in a final form without changes.
